ovdesc.p:
Scorecards could be defined in the table SA.SCORE.CARD. The ID of the record would be the same as SA.SCORE.DATA or ID of SA.SCORE.DATA : any allowed value in the linked field of CUSTOMER table (as defined in parameter file). Thus for a mortgage loan product, the ID of SA.SCORE.CARD could be MORTGAGE (as defined in SA.SCORE.DATA) or MORTGAGE-US (if separate score card is to be defined for US residents). Similarly for corporate loan product scorecard could be defined for corporate loan in general with ID as CORP.LOAN or CORP.LOAN-MFG (if separate score card is to defined for manufacturing industry).
The individual scores for each of the data can be defined in score card. Flexibility has been provided to define the score based on a data type, data group and or ratio. It is also possible to have a score based two or more data together.
For sample definitions of score card please refer to USER GUIDE.

desc.p:
The operand to decide whether ONE or ALL of the multiple conditions stipulated are to be satisfied for the rule to apply.
OR - One of the conditions should satisfy
ALL - All the conditions are to be satisfied
Example (a) - A score of 10 points is given if either ratio ABC is less than 1 or ratio CBA is less than 5. The definition in this case will be as follows;
2.1 Operand OR 3.1.1 Ratio.Type ABC 4.1.1 Decision LT 5.1.1 Decision fr 1.00 6.1.1 Decision to 3.1.2 Ratio.Type CBA 4.1.2 Decision LT 5.1.2 Decision fr 5.00 6.1.2 Decision to 7.1 FS.Score 10
Example (b) - A score of 15 is applicable if ratio DEF value is less than 1 and ABC ratio value is less than 2. In this case, the definition is as follows;
2.1 Operand AND 3.1.1 Ratio.Type DEF 4.1.1 Decision LT 5.1.1 Decision fr 1.00 6.1.1 Decision to 3.1.2 Ratio.Type ABC 4.1.2 Decision LT 5.1.2 Decision fr 2.00 6.1.2 Decision to 7.1 FS.Score 15
Note that if multiple conditions are satisfied, the scores for each satisfied set will be reckoned and hence care should be exercised in defining the rule.
Example (c) - If value of ratio ABC is less than 1 the points are 10, for value 1-1.99 the points are 15, for value 2-2.99 the points are 20 and for value greater than or equal to 3 the points are 25. In this case the definition should be as follows;
2.1 Operand OR 3.1.1 Ratio.Type ABC 4.1.1 Decision LT 5.1.1 Decision fr 1.00 6.1.1 Decision to 7.1 FS.Score 10 2.2 Operand OR 3.2.1 Ratio.Type ABC 4.2.1 Decision RG 5.2.1 Decision fr 1.00 6.2.1 Decision to 1.99 7.2 FS.Score 15 2.3 Operand OR 3.3.1 Ratio.Type ABC 4.3.1 Decision RG 5.3.1 Decision fr 2.00 6.3.1 Decision to 2.99 7.3 FS.Score 20 2.4 Operand OR 3.4.1 Ratio.Type ABC 4.4.1 Decision GE 5.4.1 Decision fr 3.00 6.4.1 Decision to 7.4 FS.Score 25
In the above case if the actual score is say 2.75 only one condition is satisfied (set 3) and hence 20 points are given.
However, if the definition is as follows for the same rule (this is an incorrect definition and should NOT be made)
2.1 Operand OR 3.1.1 Ratio.Type ABC 4.1.1 Decision LT 5.1.1 Decision fr 1.00 6.1.1 Decision to 7.1 FS.Score 10 2.2 Operand OR 3.2.1 Ratio.Type ABC 4.2.1 Decision LT 5.2.1 Decision fr 2.00 6.2.1 Decision to 7.2 FS.Score 15 2.3 Operand OR 3.3.1 Ratio.Type ABC 4.3.1 Decision LT 5.3.1 Decision fr 3.00 6.3.1 Decision to 7.3 FS.Score 20 2.4 Operand OR 3.4.1 Ratio.Type ABC 4.4.1 Decision GE 5.4.1 Decision fr 3.00 6.4.1 Decision to 7.4 FS.Score 25
In this case if the value of the calculated ration is say 0.90, conditions 1, 2 and 3 are satisfied and hence 10+15+20 = 45 points will be given.
Only allowed values are AND and OR

ID of the score card. ID could as under
a) Should be the same as SA.SCORE.DATA ID OR
b) SA.SCORE.DATA ID - ATTRIBUTE as defined in SA.SCORE.PARAMETER.
For example if MORTGAGE product score table is required by residence, then the same is defined in parameter file by linking MORTGAGE product to RESIDENCE field in CUSTOMER table. Thus score cards with different IDs can be defined as under
MORTGAGE-US or MORTGAGE-EU (the value after '-' must be an accepted value in RESIDENCE field in CUSTOMER)
Specifies the value or the start of a range of values for which the allocation of score as per field 9 applies.
Negative values not allowed. Zero allowed.
Indicates the method of scoring calculation to be used if the data is undefined.
If blank, then null will be treated as '0'.
If yes , then the field will be excluded from calculation of scores
For example
Total elements in group = 4
Total score for group = 100
If EXCL.NULL.VAL is not defined then each element will have value as 25(100/4)
If for same example, if EXCL.NULL.VALS is set, then each element should have score as 100/3
